text: Ah right cool, what course are you doing now?
I do general film
That does sound very annoying with your parents, I guess you're not the only one like that though, you may have to figure out a way to change their minds a little lol
So we study about films... analysise movies and recrease some scenes from famous movies
Ah ok, I did media studies at A level, I realised it was way too much writing for my liking
I cant write to save my life
Haha, at least you can do the filming part
One of the advantages of pipeline, is if for whatever reason we get screwed in the industry, we can transfer our skills to software :slightly_smiling_face:
Ahhh thats pretty handy
What movies have you worked on btw

When it gets to building a PC at least, I reckon the basic thing is don't go for a laptop. Even if you don't initially put in a lot of money, it's obviously a lot easier to upgrade a pc :slightly_smiling_face:
And my studio works on chrildrens animation mostly aha, it's a really nice work culture (some of the bigger studios have a lot of overtime required)
The big one at the moment is they're doing the paddington tv show
I was at the framestore event
I was very suprised to find out that paddington was made by just one studio
Haha, this is the TV show we're doing, not the film
The bosses are wanting to branch into film, but need a good investment (apparently £4m isn't good enough)
Were you good at maths in school btw?
yes i love maths
Ah cool that's great for coding then haha
well in gcses i flopped a bit and got a 7
If you'd like to learn the basics of python, I've seen so many people recommend this - <https://automatetheboringstuff.com/2e/chapter1/>
Obviously skip the later stuff like web scraping as that's quite useless for us haha
i have gotten so much "hate" for saying that html and css was a coding language omg
i used to do web developement for ICT and got pretty good at it and when asked what languages i know i would say html and css. why is it so triggering for people?
Haha, I think its a bit more of a meme for people to be annoyed at it
It is writing code, but doesn't particularly count as a language since it doesn't _do_ anything
If you expanded your html knowledge to also included php code, then that would count as a language
But php sucks, I learned on it, and I've realised python is so much nicer haha
i dont know about php but i did start learning sql
our school technician told me its good for data handling and stuff so i learnt it for a few weeks but that was like a year ago
I feel for you
I know basic SQL, it's horrible to use lol
It is however required for databases and very useful
In Python I'm using SQLAlchemy which is an object orientated wrapper over SQL

Instead of "select permission from User where username = peter", it's more like this:

user = session.query(User).filter(User.username=='peter').one()
user.permission
btw

It generates this SQL code automatically - SELECT CASE WHEN ("ApplicationVersion".version_str IS NOT NULL) THEN "ApplicationVersion".version_str ELSE CAST("ApplicationVersion".version_int AS VARCHAR) END AS anon_1, "ApplicationVersion".row_id AS "ApplicationVersion_row_id", "ApplicationVersion".application_id AS "ApplicationVersion_application_id", "ApplicationVersion".version_int AS "ApplicationVersion_version_int", "ApplicationVersion".version_str AS "ApplicationVersion_version_str", "ApplicationVersion".state AS "ApplicationVersion_state", "ApplicationVersion".created AS "ApplicationVersion_created", "ApplicationVersion".updated AS "ApplicationVersion_updated"
FROM "ApplicationVersion"
WHERE EXISTS (SELECT 1
FROM "Application"
WHERE "Application".row_id = "ApplicationVersion".application_id AND (EXISTS (SELECT 1
FROM "ApplicationLanguage", "CodingLanguage"
WHERE "Application".row_id = "ApplicationLanguage".application_id AND "CodingLanguage".row_id = "ApplicationLanguage".language_id AND "CodingLanguage".name = ?)))
do you guys use a lot of bots to automate some basic vfx
To be honest, not really
I've written some scripts to be run periodically, such as which machines to enable/disable on the render farm
That's as far as our automation goes really
One thing we're experimenting with is an event listener on some software we use. That would work by catching whatever people do, then modifying some other things depending on rules
i thought that some things that dont really need that much human touch for example some simulations wouldve been automated
Simulations are actually mostly out of our hands since their team is so small, they deal with all of that
we've made the tool for artists to submit shots to the render farm, but the artists actually need to choose the settings
Even if we did more work on simulations, the FX artists would need to send that to the farm too :slightly_smiling_face:
We can't test however as it costs £7000+ per license and there's obviously none spare lol
Houdini is ridiculously expensive
what would it take for your studio to switch to blender
like what features is it missing
I think as of right now, Blender is almost there
It's missing support for Redshift which is the renderer we use
and most of the artists know and like Maya
We've also got a ton of tools in Maya, and I've only briefly looked into Blender, and it does look harder
Harder to code stuff for I mean
Obviously python support doesn't matter to most artists, but it's definitely less "approachable" than maya's python
okay becuase i was thinking like for £7000 per license houdini must be offering some proper features
Houdini is amazing
But a super steep learning curve, so I've not figured it out yet haha
make your mind houdini or maya
Houdini for effects, Maya for modelling/animation
Katana is apparently amazing for lighting, but that's a good £4k per license too, so we use Maya for that too :stuck_out_tongue:
i thought it was zbrush for modeling
Good point, I guess it is for detailed modelling
If you were making a chair or something I guess, probably a bit overkill to go into zbrush
One of our environment guys was looking into building environments procedurally using houdini a few months back
Not sure how far he got with that
The main two programs used in most studios are Maya and Nuke
wait by procedural environment do you mean like the landscapes would be generated using a formula
Those are the most useful to learn as of right now. Perhaps in a few years it'll be Unreal Engine and Blender :stuck_out_tongue:
Something like that
I don't exactly know the details, it'd make all the modellers lives easier though
i dont understand the node based system in nuke
i just generally dont understand why companies prefer node bases systems than layer based
It's so much more versatile
With a layer based system, you're limited to something quite linear
In Nuke for example
you could branch one point into two, deal with them independantly, then join them together again
It makes AE feel super clunky to use after you get used to it
Word of warning though, pirating most VFX programs is fair game, but DO NOT pirate Nuke ever, they're very trigger happy with fines
yea i made 100% sure i would never touch any of foudrys products
Ah good haha
Our commercials department still use AE for it's quick turnaround time, productions only use Nuke though as that's seen as the industry standard right now
im going to download a free alternate
So yeah, I guess basically, node based is very powerful, just a bit harder to learn and get going initially
There's fusion which is a free/cheap rival of Nuke
also one thing that annoys me
there's talk we'll be trying it out, they're worried about switching though as most people won't know it, so hiring will be harder
yea i have it and am  going to mess with it later
:0 i mean it would cut lots of cost
Haha yeah
but one thing i dont like about nuke or the others is that
I had a quick play in it, struggled to do any python at all
It's library is very weird and lacking
it can only edit on scene at a time
You can edit multiple :stuck_out_tongue:
I've noticed even if I don't do anything, unless I don't go on file>clear, it'll open a new window and keep the current scene open
no i mean for eg in after effects
you arrange your clips
Ah ok
set up your like cuts and that sync and then go into each scene and add your effects
You mean like the compositions?
yea
It's been a while since I last used AE haha
It worked well but as soon as I saw Nuke I didn't like AE anymore :stuck_out_tongue:
u traitor
haha
It's just sad that the cost scales with how awesome the programs are
I'm assuming AE is relatively cheap :stuck_out_tongue:
yea you pay a monthly fee and get access to the whole adobe package
my school pays for it so i dont really need to worry about the costs
The IT team right now is literally talking about phasing out more adobe haha
About maybe scrapping photoshop for something else called affinity
apparently adobe have gotten pretty smug in the sense that, since they dont have that much competitions they arent really working on their products as they should
affinity is a one time payment and is only £25... thats amazing
That's a problem with a lot of the software
Maya is a mess, but they have the market, so they're not innovating
The foundary has the market, so they're not going cheaper
Houdini is the only one that's earned their price. Apparently they keep rewriting the entire program to make it faster and more stable
The guy I work with is hoping that Autodesk start getting worried about blender and step up their game lol
nah let them stay like this then blender shall take over the industry
Our boss has a 5 year plan to move to blender btw
A lot of the big studios won't be doing it though
They're still stuck on Maya 2015 because change is hard when you hit a certain size
if some artists are finding it hard tell them to watch the donut tutorial
It's more their tools lol
In our medium company, we're making these nice little tools
in the big companies, they're building render engines and crazy stuff
Probably hundreds of hours of work just to change version
oh yea i was going to ask that
how complex is a render engine
i was in a discord server and these programmers were thinking of making their own render engine, they made it sound easy
Never even looked into it haha, sounds very complex though
It probably crosses over with games programming
yea
omg i saw these sets
where they had led
backgrounds
You'd need to read papers on how light interacts with materials, code that, read how light interacts with water, code that, read how shadows work, code that, etc
Yeah like the mandelorean
yes
OMG
I don't really understand why they're so useful tbf haha
i was sooooooo fascinated
Would have thought it's a lot more limited :stuck_out_tongue:
But yeah, the coders definitely had a strong hand in that lol
its fixes so much problems on lighting, travelling to find acc sets and decreases the ammount of cgi  environements
oh and actors also get a sense of where they are instead of staring at green screens
It's still a cgi environment though :stuck_out_tongue:
Good point about the actors
I would have thought it's very limited with lighting, you're stuck with what the screen can project so you can't manually position any near the actor
Obviously it is quite good, I just don't really get how they fix all the drawbacks of using it lol
fair
another thing that suprised me the most was
i was researching explosions for a history essay and found out that the company that imports the most explosives other than the us mlitary is dysney
Haha wtf
I'm not a huge fan of disney to be fair, they've kinda got to the "evil massive company" stage who owns everything
I'll be back after lunch btw :stuck_out_tongue:
oki
im still shook that they own 35% of hollywood, i might write an essay about them and soft power politics
Ah that's insane haha, I guess they do own marvel and star wars now though
